text: our main story security is tight in the
German city of Hamburg for the start of
the g20 summit after night of violent
clashes between riot police and
anti-capitalist protesters items on the
agenda will be trade climate change and
North Korea the American and Russian
president will be meeting for the first
time and Theresa May will call on world
leaders to work together to cut off
funding to terrorist groups our
diplomatic correspondent James Robbins
reports from Hamburg a global summit
automatically triggered protests from
those who accuse the world's most
powerful leaders of serving narrow
interests welcome to hell is one slogan
to greet the presidents and prime
ministers for themselves divided over a
huge range of issues but most eyes are
focused on the controversial figure of
President Donald Trump his summit hosts
Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel
facing elections to showed her anger in
the past over the president's
denunciation of the Paris climate change
agreement but she's now hoping to
combine toughness with a search for some
common ground
the real prize fight here will be mr.
Trump's first presidential bout with
Russia's Vladimir Putin on his way here
president Trump acknowledged the
possibility Russia interfered in the
American elections at the same time he
accused Russia of deliberate
destabilization through its actions in
Ukraine these are charges denied by
Vladimir Putin on the Kremlin the two
President may find some common ground
but this very personal contest
symbolizes deep divisions among the
wider leadership of the most powerful
economies in the world disputes over
trade and how to confront North Korea
are among other highly contentious
issues China with Russia wants to keep
the focus on dialogue the Prime Minister
Theresa May has come to Hamburg pledging
to continue a campaign to outlaw the
financing of violent extremism she will
present some new ideas for International
Cooperation to try to identify and close
down even small-scale channeling of
funds to lone attackers
all summit throw division into sharp
relief but still this one feels
exceptional James Robbins BBC News
Hamburg let's go live now to James
Robbins in Hamburg and James as you were
saying there I mean obviously g20 but
it's effectively g2 in particular who
are really getting all the attention and
it's lots of anticipation about what
it's going to be like when Trump and
Putin come together that's absolutely
right and it's not wrong I think to
focus on this political prize fight this
showdown between two rivals on the world
stage who've never met before
as president it's a meeting scheduled
for perhaps 3035 minutes according to
the White House quite relatively short
and it will be what the cameras reveal a
short time that they're present which I
think most people will be trying to
analyze the two leaders squaring up to
each other one Donald Trump actually
some seven inches taller some 18
centimetres taller than the Russian
president but the Russian president
brings to this of course all the
experience that often can carry you
through really tough meetings where
Donald Trump has been in office for what
170 days less than six months President
Putin can look back over 17 years at the
top of power so in many ways it's an
unequal contest how will it play out
well we've yet to see that it I think
crystallizes all the uncertainty in a
rather rudderless world which the other
leaders are feeling at this summit James
thank you very much
